metadata.sermon_start_end: We’re looking at the basic beliefs of the Christian faith, and there’s no way to do that without getting to what the Bible says is wrong with us. It’s really obvious to everyone that human beings can do an awful lot of very bad things, really evil things. [...] Those are fig leaves, and the pitiful fig leaves of your own making will never, ever actually clothe you the way the love of Christ will. It’ll never really deal with the deep down self-doubt you have, but this will handle that. Don’t you want this? Get Jesus Christ’s healing. Let’s pray.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon stays close to the narrative of Genesis 3, but it tends to treat the text as a 'classic' or 'foundational' illustration of a general doctrine (Sin) rather than seeking what is unique to this specific pericope. It uses the text to validate a systematic-theological framework (root, essence, signs, solution).
quotes: there’s no more classic or more foundational place than the great story of the Serpent
It tells you pretty much everything top level you need to know.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more on the specific literary details of the Genesis narrative—such as the specific dialogue structure—to find what this text says that 'The Fall' as a general concept does not.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no explicit mention of Hebrew or the specific historical-religious context of ancient Israel. The exegesis is largely psychological and systematic. The preacher interprets the 'tree' through the lens of modern obedience rather than the ancient Near Eastern context of 'knowledge of good and evil'.
quotes: He doesn’t say, 'Don’t eat the tree because it’s fattening.' For New Yorkers, that would have been enough.
Martin Luther has said it best... incurvatus se
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the original meaning of 'knowledge of good and evil' in its ancient context to ground the exposition in scholarship rather than modern psychological categories.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is very concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist'. It identifies the modern drive for self-justification through work, status, and moralism. It speaks directly to the 'New Yorker' identity of achievement as a 'fig leaf'.
quotes: I see people out there exhausting themselves trying to control everything, to make sure their family and their children and their health and their finances and everything will be fine
New Yorkers, you work so hard. You want to look good. You want to have a great résumé.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid the 'sidebar' style of application; ensure the contemporary analysis flows directly from the text's specific mechanics rather than general observations about city life.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a thematic structure (1. Root, 2. Essence, etc.) which risks separating 'what it meant' from 'what it means'. However, within each section, the preacher moves quickly between the biblical narrative and the hearer's heart.
quotes: As we take a look at this narrative, we’re going to learn about the root of sin, the essence of sin...
That, friends, is the lie of the Serpent that has passed into, indeed, every human heart.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Move away from the 'three-point' lecture structure to allow the 'present of revelation' to emerge more organically from the text's own movement.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is a textbook example of preaching 'misery' (incurvatus se) and 'redemption' (the cross). It avoids being 'too objective' by grounding sin in human psychology and the lack of trust.
quotes: His misery is his misery before God... 'Eichmann is in all of us.'
salvation is God taking your place and my place
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' part is somewhat thin, focusing more on 'healing' than on the specific life of service that follows redemption.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'lostness' is primarily described as psychological exhaustion and 'self-doubt'. While it mentions 'certainly die', the existential weight of eternal or temporal destruction is softened into a lack of 'self-worth'.
quotes: It’ll never really deal with the deep down self-doubt you have
you have a sense of condemnation you can’t shake.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Make the 'two ways' more explicit. The consequence of sin should be presented with the gravity of 'destruction' or 'loss' rather than just 'anxiety' or 'exhaustion'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher uses the 'Two Adams' typology to move from the text to the Cross. Grace is presented as the only solution to the 'lie' of the serpent.
quotes: Jesus reverses the work of the Serpent... through a tree.
The tree of life for all, but only me
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the connection between Genesis 3 and Christ is not merely a clever 'reversal' trope but is rooted in the specific 'Word' that God speaks in the garden.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 24 minutes, the sermon meets Dekker's requirement for breadth. It allows space for anecdotes (Eichmann, Ferguson) and theological reflection (Luther, Herbert).
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Use the available time to deepen the linguistic exegesis (Thesis 2) rather than relying on multiple external anecdotes.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong example of 'human-oriented' preaching that takes the 'misery' of the hearer seriously, yet it falls short of Dekker's requirement for rigorous linguistic exegesis and the specific 'nowhere else' quality of the text. It leans heavily on systematic categories (Luther's incurvatus se) and psychological analysis, which occasionally causes the specific Bible passage to 'sleep' under the weight of the preacher's theological framework.
strengths: Effective actualization of the 'misery' of the modern hearer (Thesis 5).
Clear Christocentric telos using the 'tree' typology (Thesis 7).
Adequate length to allow for theological 'breadth' (Thesis 8).
weaknesses: Lack of explicit linguistic (Greek/Hebrew) or historical-critical depth (Thesis 2).
The 'two ways' are reduced to psychological states rather than ultimate destinations (Thesis 6).
The sermon treats the text as a general illustration of 'Sin' rather than a unique word (Thesis 1).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a functional sermon that rightly identifies the Gospel as the 'recreation' of the Word, but it risks becoming a 'speech about the gospel' rather than a specific exposition of Genesis 3. It meets the formal criteria but lacks the exegetical sharpness Dekker demands of a 'bicycle mechanic' of the Word.
